Result.Abstract: A system whose expected state changes with time cannot have both a forward-directed translationally invariant probabilistic law and a backward-directed translationally invariant law. When faced with this choice, science seems to favor the former. An asymmetry between cause and effect may help to explain why temporally oriented laws are usually forward-directed.
Result.Title: Temporally oriented laws

Result.Abstract: When philosophers defend epiphenomenalist doctrines, they often do so by way of a priori arguments. Here we suggest an empirical approach that is modeled on August Weismann's experimental arguments against the inheritance of acquired characters. Result.Title: Epiphenomenalism - the Do's and the Don'ts

Result.Abstract: Modus Darwin is a principle of inference that licenses the conclusion that two species have a common ancestor, based on the observation that they are similar. The present paper investigates the principle's probabilistic foundations.

Result.Abstract: Abstract: Only one traditional objection to Pascal's wager is telling: Pascal assumes,a particular theology, but without justification. We produce two new objections that go deeper. Result.Title: Absence of evidence and evidence of absence: evidential transitivity in connection with fossils, fishing, fine-tuning, and firing squads
